Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Ellison M. Carter of the University of Texas at Austin to conduct a research project, entitled "Advanced monitoring techniques for indoor air pollution from solid fuel combustion," during the summer of 2012 at Tsinghua University in Beijing, China. The host scientist is Dr. Xudong Yang.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the development of air pollutant monitoring techniques that are robust and rugged for application in the field and the creation of new metrics to evaluate indoor air pollution generated from biomass combustion relative to coal combustion, paying particular attention to compounds with known adverse health impacts that have been seldom studied in the field. This field-based study would be the first to quantify and compare previously ignored toxic emissions resulting from household biomass and coal combustion, providing information that is crucial to the development of effective remediation and health intervention strategies that target reductions in toxic emissions. The study promises to fill a knowledge gap by studying indoor air pollutants that have been previously ignored in rural populations and are suspected or known to have significant health impacts.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

Indoor Air Pollution from Biomass Fuel Combustion in Semi-Gasifier Stoves

PI: Ellison M. Carter

Mentor: Dr. Xudong Yang, Tsinghua University

03 August 2012

 

As Chinese researchers continue to expand their international presence across a wide range of scholarly disciplines, foreign researchers have an ever-growing interest in collaborating with their Chinese counterparts. On fellowship as a first-time foreign researcher in China, I can attest to what an exciting time it is to build partnerships within the Chinese scientific community. I sought the NSF EAPSI fellowship to extend my research expertise, initiate professional relationships I hope to cultivate throughout my scholarly career, and learn about Chinese culture and society. Three aspects critical to what I consider to be a successful professional experience have been sustained mentorship, expeditious access to resources and professional networks, and mutually beneficial research goals, to say nothing of the fulfilling personal time I have spent trying to gain understanding of life in China.

My Chinese advisor and the senior-level graduate and postdoctoral students with whom I worked were excellent mentors. Their mentorship led to several timely opportunities including: 1) giving a guest lecture on Introductory Concepts in Toxicology for a researcher teaching a course on the Fundamentals of Environmental Epidemiology at the Graduate University for the Chinese Academy of Sciences, 2) attending an international workshop on Field Emissions Measurements and an international meeting between the Global Alliance for Clean Cookstoves and the Chinese Alliance for Clean Stoves, and 3) working at the Beijing University of Chemical Technology, the Biomass and Renewable Energy lab, and the Rural Energy and Environments lab (REEL). These opportunities were vital to enabling me to carry out the research I designed and to effectively disseminate my results.

Safe, clean, efficient energy-producing systems are needed in China to serve rural domestic energy needs and maintain a high level of public health. My research focused on evaluating the impact an emerging class of cooking and heating stoves, designed for solid fuel combustion, have on indoor air pollution. Very little data is available on the class of stoves that I came to Tsinghua University to study, so the data I proposed to collect was very useful to my host, while the process of collecting this data was valuable in my development as a young researcher. The preliminary results from my work suggest that some gasifier stoves are capable of achieving much lower emissions of particulate matter, which is highly desirable from a health perspective, without sacrificing energy performance. However, there is large variation in performance by this class of stoves with respect to carbon monoxide emissions. These results are highly relevant not only to the academic community and various levels within the Chinese government, but also to stove manufacturers in China, who maintain strong relationships with Chinese scholars and with whom this information is most likely to be shared.

Before wide-scale stove interventions could be undertaken, as has been done before in China, it is vital to understand not only how a given stove performs in a laboratory test, but also how well it performs under conditions that best mimic the performance it will produce in a real environment. To this end, I conducted a series of experiments designed to simulate typical Chinese cooking scenarios, and the data have been useful in our effort to understand relationships between household room air concentrations of hazardous air pollutants and the emissions measurements of these same pollutants from combustions devices.
